data.event: However, the first written reference to the town dates back to 1247, when monks from Bardejov complained to King Béla IV about a violation of the town’s borders by Prešov, a neighbouring city.

event.title: is mentioned in Hypatian Codex for 1240

data.event: The city is mentioned in Hypatian Codex for 1240 when in the fall Daniel of Galicia passed it traveling from Hungary to Poland.
In 1320, King Charles Robert granted the settlers extensive city privileges and the town speedily began to grow.
In 1352, the town was granted the privilege to set up an annual fair (jarmok) dedicated to St. Aegidius on September 1.

event.title: dedicated to St. Aegidius on September 1

The deed mentions a new construction of the town of Bardejov with an order by King Louis I to fortify it.[1] The entire defensive circuit was completed, with three gates on the main routes and bastions at strategic points.[2] In 1376, the King Ladislaus I granted Bardejov the status of a free royal town.

event.title: granted the town storage privileges in 1402

data.event: Zigmund of Luxemburg granted the town storage privileges in 1402, for the goods brought here by the Russian and Polish merchants.
